awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Fabrication of self-powered scaffolds for enhanced bone repair
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Mei Wei
Proposal ID: 1347130

More than 1.3 million bone-repair procedures are conducted every year in the USA, which constitutes a large proportion of the medical bills of the society. Despite of the huge demand in bone grafting materials, many currently available grafting materials still exhibit poor efficiency in bone regeneration. Thus, there is a pressing need for the development of new grafting materials aimed at faster and better bone regeneration. In this study, we propose to fabricate self-powered scaffolds with good biodegradability, excellent osteoconductivitiy and osteoinductivitiy, and capable of inducing in-situ DC electric stimulation. The specific aims of the study are:
(1) Fabrication of biodegradable scaffolds capable of generating in-situ DC electric field with controlled electric current direction; and (2) Evaluations of the in vitro cell-nanobattery incorporated-scaffolds interactions, and determine the optimum nanobattery loading for stimulating cell activities without resulting in toxic effects.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research is highly innovative across fields of tissue engineering, nanotechnology, electrochemistry, developmental biology, and orthopedics, which explores a completely new approach for better and faster bone repair and regeneration. Its intellectual merits can be summarized into the following two aspects: (1) The fabrication of self-powered scaffolds for in situ generation of DC electric field to stimulate osteoprogenitor activities; (2) Alignment of nanobatteries in the apatite/collagen scaffold via dielectrophoresis; (3) The employment of a 4-D imaging platform for real-time observation of the interactions between nanobattery and GFP-labeled cells to elucidate mechanisms of electric stimulation on osteoblastic cells. It is for the first time that self-powered electrical stimulation is used in conjunction with tissue engineering scaffold to produce early and high-quality new bone formation.

Broader Impacts: The proposed application explores a completely new approach to apply in situ DC electric stimulation to bone tissue engineering. The successful implementation of the proposed study will address directly the existing problems of bone tissue engineering scaffolds, such as poor osteoconductivity, lack of osteoinductivity, and slow bone healing. Its approach may also provide an effective solution to non-union and delayed union of bone repair in conditioned patients, such as aging, diabetics, osteoporosis patients. Thus, the proposed research will be significant and transformative to the tissue engineering field as it will result in a new generation of tissue engineering scaffold which is not only osteoconductive, but also osteoinductive with the capability of stimulating new bone formation in define areas. The strategies established here can also be used to stimulate other cells for tissue repair and regeneration other than bone, such as blood vessel, never, cartilage, etc. It is expected that the novel approach will greatly shorten the rehabilitation time of patients and thereby substantially lower medical costs associated with hospitalization, health care, etc for the society. Thus, the social and economic impact of the proposed project is invaluable. Also, this project will result in the training of two graduate students and a number of undergraduate students in areas of tissue engineering and electrochemistry, while exposing them to a multidisciplinary research environment. Efforts will be made to recruit females and minority students by integrating our research activities with existing recruiting efforts at the Departmental as well as Institutional levels. A plan is made to participate in activities organized by various professional societies dedicated to underrepresented minorities. In addition, K- 12 outreach will also be carried out to target high school students, especially females and underrepresented minorities, excited about regenerative engineering. The results obtained from the project will be disseminated broadly via publishing in scientific journals, presenting in conferences and publicizing to general public web site.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
More than 1.3 million bone-repair procedures are conducted every year in the USA, which constitutes a large portion of today's medical expenses. The potential for nonunion or delayed union of fractured bone fragments increases substantially when a patient is an avid smoker or suffers from illness such as diabetes. With the ever-aging current population, the number of nonunion is growing dramatically each year. To address this problem, the newly emerged field of tissue engineering has offered great promise to repair bone defects using a combination of scaffold matrix and bone progenitor cells. Despite the immense demand of bone grafting materials, many currently available grafting materials still exhibit relatively poor bone regeneration. Thus, there is a pressing need for the development of new grafting materials aimed at faster and better bone regeneration.

Intellectual Merit: In this study, we have successfully synthesized intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils with adjustable mineral contents and compositions using both linear and brushlike polymers to mimic the sequestration function of non-collagenous proteins (NCPs) in inducing intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils seen in nature (Figure 1). The mechanisms of intrafibrillar mineralization of collagen fibrils induced by these polymer analogs were explored (Figure 2). The intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils were then formed into multi-level biomimetic lamellar scaffolds via a two-step co-precipitation and lyophilization approach (Figure 3). In vitro cell culture studies have confirmed that the optimal scaffold groups are superior in supporting bone cell activities compared to traditional cellular scaffolds. These scaffolds can be promising candidates as bone grafting materials.

In addition, bioresorbable Zn-polypyrrole (PPy) nanobatteries have been successfully developed using a template-based electrodeposition process. The preparation of Zn-PPy composite nanobatteries is extremely challenging as electrodeposition of Zn requires a negative potential, while electropolymerization of PPy requires a positive potential. In order to achieve Zn-PPy nanobatteries, a passivation layer was deposited between Zn and PPy to make these two processes compatible. Through this special procedure, Zn-PPy nanobatteris were successfully prepared for the first time. Figure 4 shows the cyclic voltammetry curves, indicating the typical formation peak (ca. 0.6 V) of zinc salicylate and polypyrrole oxidation deposition process, while Figure 5 shows the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the as-prepared Zn-PPy segmented nanobatteries. These nanobatteries were incorporated into the biomimetic bone scaffold to create self-powered scaffolds. It was expected that the nanobatteries would generate an in-situ DC electric field to stimulate cell activities. Our in vitro cell culture study suggested that nanobatteries alone demonstrated an inhibitory effect on MC3T3-E1 cell proliferation, but the cells still proliferated with time. In contrast, the nanobattery-containing scaffolds exhibited good biocompatibility (Figure 6). They support cell activities comparable to the control, the collagen-apatite scaffold without nanobatteries.

Broader Impacts: The proposed project has a broader impact on various scientific disciplines. The development of these novel tissue engineering scaffolds may lead to better and faster bone repair than currently available treatments, reducing costs associated with hospitalization and healthcare for society, and increasing the quality of life of patients. In addition, the novel Zn-PPy nanobatteries developed can also be incorporated into other matrices to create new conductive materials for applications such as energy.

This project also allowed us to train a few graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of tissue engineering and electrochemistry, while exposing them to a multidisciplinary research environment. The results obtained from the project have been disseminated broadly via publishing in high-impact scientific journals, presenting in conferences, and incorporating into independent studies offered by the PI and the Co-PI.


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Mei Wei

  • Bright-field (A to C) and HAADF TEM (D to F) images of intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils using PAA (A, B), PEG-COOH (C, D), or PEG-PAA (E, F) as a sequestration analog. The inset in C suggests that the minerals deposited are either nanocrystalline or amorphous.
    Le Yu

    Le Yu
    Copyrighted

    Figure 3
  • Typical cyclic voltammetry curves for electrodeposition of passivation layer and polypyrrole on top of Zn nanowires in a PCM template. The peak at ca. 0.6 V implies the formation of zinc salicylate.
    Qiuchen Dong and Yu Lei
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 4
  • Representative SEM images of Zn-PPy segmented nanowires (Scale bar=1 micron). (A) Three Zn-PPy nanowires on an AAO template. The yellow-pink lines are drawn to show the structure of the nanowires. (B) The as-prepared two-segmented Zn-PPy nanowires on a copper tape surface.
    Qiuchen Dong and Yu Lei
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 5
  • Cell proliferation of MC3T3 cells cultured within Col-HA scaffolds with or without nanobatteries.
    Le Yu
    Mei Wei
    Figure 6

More than 1.3 million bone-repair procedures are conducted every year in the USA, which constitutes a large portion of today's medical expenses. The potential for nonunion or delayed union of fractured bone fragments increases substantially when a patient is an avid smoker or suffers from illness such as diabetes. With the ever-aging current population, the number of nonunion is growing dramatically each year. To address this problem, the newly emerged field of tissue engineering has offered great promise to repair bone defects using a combination of scaffold matrix and bone progenitor cells. Despite the immense demand of bone grafting materials, many currently available grafting materials still exhibit relatively poor bone regeneration. Thus, there is a pressing need for the development of new grafting materials aimed at faster and better bone regeneration.

Intellectual Merit: In this study, we have successfully synthesized intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils with adjustable mineral contents and compositions using both linear and brushlike polymers to mimic the sequestration function of non-collagenous proteins (NCPs) in inducing intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils seen in nature (Figure 1). The mechanisms of intrafibrillar mineralization of collagen fibrils induced by these polymer analogs were explored (Figure 2). The intrafibrillar mineralized collagen fibrils were then formed into multi-level biomimetic lamellar scaffolds via a two-step co-precipitation and lyophilization approach (Figure 3). In vitro cell culture studies have confirmed that the optimal scaffold groups are superior in supporting bone cell activities compared to traditional cellular scaffolds. These scaffolds can be promising candidates as bone grafting materials.

In addition, bioresorbable Zn-polypyrrole (PPy) nanobatteries have been successfully developed using a template-based electrodeposition process. These nanobatteries were incorporated into the biomimetic bone scaffold to create self-powered scaffolds. It was expected that the nanobatteries would generate an in-situ DC electric field to stimulate cell activities. Our in vitro cell culture study suggested that nanobatteries alone demonstrated an inhibitory effect on MC3T3-E1 cell proliferation, but the cells still proliferated with time. In contrast, the nanobattery-containing scaffolds exhibited good biocompatibility (Figure 6). They support cell activities comparable to the control, the collagen-apatite scaffold without nanobatteries.

Broader Impacts: The proposed project has a broader impact on various scientific disciplines. The development of these novel tissue engineering scaffolds may lead to better and faster bone repair than currently available treatments, reducing costs associated with hospitalization and healthcare for society, and increasing the quality of life of patients. In addition, the novel Zn-PPy nanobatteries developed can also be incorporated into other matrices to create new conductive materials for applications such as energy.

This project also allowed us to train a few graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of tissue engineering and electrochemistry, while exposing them to a multidisciplinary research environment. The results obtained from the project have been disseminated broadly via publishing in high-impact scientific journals, presenting in conferences, and incorporating into independent studies offered by the PI and the Co-PI.
